Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Pre- and Syn-Rift Extension, Magmatism and Segmentation along the Eastern North American Margin
Award.AbstractNarration:
The eastern North America margin of the U.S. is a mature continental margin formed by the breakup of the supercontinent Pangaea and the opening of the Atlantic Ocean ~175-140 million years ago. The margin has experienced some of the largest recorded Quaternary offshore slope failures (e.g., the Currituck landslide and Grand Banks landslide and tsunami) within the last 2 million years, and large recent (magnitude 5.9 2011 Mineral, VA) and historic (magnitude 7.3 1886 Charleston, SC) earthquakes. These events highlight the potential hazards as the margin continues to evolve today, millions of years after the cessation of rifting. Using a recently acquired onshore-offshore seismic dataset, this project will delineate crustal and basin structure within the coastal plains and continental shelf of North Carolina and southern Virginia, to understand the processes involved in rift initiation and passive margin evolution. Understanding rift formation and evolution is an active area of research within the hazard community as well as the energy sector, with impacts that relate to many fields such as hazard mitigation, land use planning, local fishing, and tourist economies. The project supports the training of two graduate students, one at the University of New Mexico (a minority serving institution) and the other at Southern Methodist University.


This project investigates the relationship between extension, magmatism and margin segmentation in the early stages of western Atlantic rifting using the amphibious active-source seismic dataset collected during the Eastern North American Margin (ENAM) Community Seismic Experiment. Analysis of two margin-normal seismic refraction profiles spanning the coastline from extended continental crust to mature oceanic crust and of one margin-parallel profile along the rupture zone and the East Coast Magnetic Anomaly will constrain the record of early extension onshore, define the continental-oceanic transition and the lateral extent of pre- and syn-rift magma emplacement and margin segmentation. Analysis of 2-D seismic reflection profiles across the continent-ocean transition will delineate along-strike and margin-dip variations of seaward-dipping reflections age and character, of pre- syn- and post-rift sedimentary sequences, and igneous basement character and crustal structure. The data will provide critical information about margin segmentation during rift initiation and evolution and magmatic distribution. The ENAM is a well-preserved, mature rifted margin created during the breakup of the supercontinent Pangea in the Mesozoic that records multiple stages of Paleozoic continental amalgamation, lithospheric breakup and the interaction with the Central Atlantic Magmatic Province (CAMP), one of the largest and most enigmatic igneous provinces worldwide. This project will examine how magmatism is distributed along and across the margin, how it correlates with both pre-existing suture zones and with modern segmentation at mid-oceanic ridges, and whether the margin is overprinted by the voluminous CAMP emplacement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The theory of plate tectonics and the continental drift hypothesis are predicated on the evidence that throughout the history of our planet, continental masses ruptured, fragments dispersed, and new oceans opened. And yet, one of the outstanding paradoxes of plate tectonics is that numerous studies continue to demonstrate that extensional plate tectonic forces alone are not sufficient to exceed the strength of cold continental lithosphere, suggesting that additional mechanisms intervene to weaken the continental lithosphere and/or localize deformation. This project hinges on the hypotheses that magmatism and partial melting conjure with preexisting zones of weakness to focus deformation, nucleate rupture and control the subsequent evolution of rifting and margin architecture. In particular, the project explores the relationship between the amount and distribution of magma during syn-rift and role that magma plays in the crustal modification and deformation in post-rift stages. Does the amount of magma change along strike of the margin? Do regions with more voluminous magmatism experience more intense deformation (i.e. thinning)? Do pre-existing features control the distribution/emplacement/intrusion of magma?

To explore these questions we exploited the dataset acquired as part of the Eastern North American Margin (ENAM) Community Seismic Experiment (CSE), a comprehensive new data-collection effort that acquired and made available to the community upon acquisition a nested, multiscale, onshore-offshore, controlled- and passive-source seismic dataset across the Cape Hatteras region, in the western Atlantic shore. The specific datasets used for this project include crustal-scale seismic reflection and refraction data collected offshore with the R/V Marcus G. Langseth and ocean bottom seismometers (OBS). The profiles span the coastline and extend over the stretched continental crust through the mature oceanic crust. This region preserves records of shallow intrusives, volcaniclastic material, imaged by seismic reflection profiles as seaward dipping reflectors (SDRs), and deep magmatism, modeled by wide-angle seismic profiles as very high velocity anomalies preserved in the lower crust. The specific goal of the project was therefore to carefully image the shallow and deep igneous crust along the portion of the margin where the SDRs and the very high velocity lower crust have been interpreted to reside, in order to assess volume, timing and role of magmatism in the early stages of rifting.  

The multichannel seismic (MCS) reflection data were carefully processed to mitigate the presence of coherent noise resulting from the pervasive water bottom multiples particularly severe along the shelf portion of the margin, which overlap and obscure the detail and mimic the geometry of the SDRs wedges and of any feature in the igneous crust. Additional imaging challenges in the region are posed by the presence of salt deposited atop the basement, which limits depth penetration, and the presence of locally very strong current, part of the Gulf Stream, which results in extreme feathering (i.e. a lateral deviation of the recording instruments from the sailing line). These problems were addressed during data processing with tailored strategies to enhance imaging where possible, and included mitigation of water bottom reverberating energy through iterative routines of surface-related multiple elimination (SRME) and parabolic Radon filtering. The interpretation of the MCS data was integrated with coincident wide-angle seismic velocity models and potential field data, to characterize the structure, syn- and post-rift deformation of the continental lithosphere across and along the margin. Across the margin, the data image a southeastward sloping, weakly faulted breakup unconformity at the base of the postrift sedimentary units. Seaward and beneath these post-rift units, SDRs are imaged over a short distance, although they disappear at the slope. Moho reflections beneath the shelf are visible dipping toward the southeast at about 9.5-11 s TWTT (27-33 km) depth. Parallel to the margin, the igneous crust exhibits variable reflectivity. To the south of Cape Hatteras, bright, discontinuous reflections, which we interpret as the SDR corresponding to the volcaniclastic wedge, are mostly found in the upper 5 km of the crust. Moving north, reflectivity fades and disappear north of Cape Hatteras, likely due to lack of energy penetration in the crust due to a combination of scattering associated with rugged bathymetry, presence of salt atop the igneous basement and severe feathering in the region. Where reflectivity in the igneous crust is successfully imaged, the thickness of the reflective packages correlates with the region of magnetic source for the East Coast Magnetic Anomaly (ECMA), as modeled along the margin by Greene et al. (2021).

The project supported the training of a MSc student.
